title: Franking credit plan created 'vulnerability and anxiety': Bill Shorten
text:
“Now I accept just the holus bolus rollout of franking credits created an anxiety in parts of the community especially amongst older Australians, both in reality, but also left them susceptible to the argument that there were further changes.”

Mr Shorten said he accepted the result as he would have "owned it" if he'd won.

"One thing that I did decide immediately right in the hour when I realised that we were going to lose is that I should take responsibility – that's why I stepped down as leader.

It is my intention to try and be in public life for the next 20 years. — Bill Shorten

"I just thought the buck stops with me at me so I've got to take responsibility."

Elected in 2007, the 52-year-old led Labor to losses in 2016 and 2017.

Now the opposition spokesman for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, he said he plans to stay in politics for the long term and confirmed he would contest the next poll, due by 2022, in his seat of Maribyrnong.

Mr Shorten responded "no" when asked if he wanted the top role again.

Advertisement

"I've hung up my leadership running shoes and I support Anthony [Albanese].

"It is my intention to try and be in public life for the next 20 years," Mr Shorten said.

Shadow treasurer Jim Chalmers told Sky News the party needed to learn from the loss, including on tax policies.

“Clearly we couldn’t build enough support for them and so we need to have a hard headed looked at them,” he said.

“That can’t have been an easy interview for Bill to give. I think he did it in a characteristically classy way. In lots of ways he’s set an example for the rest of us.

“We all need to pick ourselves up and dust ourselves off after the election.

“I think what Bill’s done, to be a champion for Australians with a disability and people who are being hounded by the government’s robo-debt program, has been terrific. I pay tribute to Bill for doing that.

“His views on the policies we took to the election obviously carry a lot of weight. He made a series of points, including that it’s possible that we took too many issues to the election and that made it hard to build the case for them.

“We may have spread ourselves too thin. We do need to listen to the message that was sent us on election night. We should have won the election and we didn’t. We’ve got things to learn from that."

Dr Chalmers said Labor wouldn't take an identical set of policies to the next election.
description: The former Labor leader says he plans stay another 20 years in federal politics, after taking the blame for Labor's loss in May.
